LING 99. Independent Studies In Linguist.description: Intended for the study of special areas within Linguistics.

LING 2G.title: EMS: Intermediate Graduate Writing for International Students
LING 2G.prereq_description: Placement based on English Language Placement Examination.
LING 2G.comments: Workload credit only. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LING 2G.description: Provides instruction for students needing to improve accuracy and fluency in written academic English.  Emphasizes grammar, vocabulary and patterns of organization relevant to academic writing at the graduate level.

LING 3A.title: EMS:  Academic English
LING 3A.prereq_description: Placement based on Analytical Writing Placement Exam (AWPE)and English
LING 3A.description: First of three levels intended to develop proficiency in       university-level reading and writing.  Emphasizes applying critical  approaches to reading, practicing writing in a variety of academic   styles, and developing grammatical and lexical resources appropriate to  a university setting.

LING 3B.title: EMS: Academic English
LING 3B.prereq_description: Open to students who have a Ling 3B placement or a prerequisite of Ling 3A with a pass grade.
LING 3B.description: Second level in a three-course series intended to develop proficiency in university-level reading and writing. Emphasizes applying critical   approaches to reading, practicing writing in a variety of academic styles, and developing grammatical and lexical resources appropriate to a    university setting.

LING 3C.title: EMS: Academic English
LING 3C.prereq_description: Open to students who have a Linguistics 3C placement; or Linguistics 3B
LING 3C.description: Third level in a three-course series intended to develop proficiency in university-level reading and writing. Emphasizes applying critical approaches to reading, practicing writing in a variety of academic styles, and developing grammatical and lexical resources appropriate to a university setting.

LING 3G.title: EMS: Advanced Graduate Writing for International Students
LING 3G.prereq_description: Graduate standing. Placement based on English Language Placement Examination scores.
LING 3G.comments: Workload credit only. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LING 3G.description: Focuses on rhetorical strategies and patterns of development used in a variety of writing typically required for graduate courses.  Addresses levels of formality and academic conventions used across disciplines, emphasizing clarity of expression.

LING 4.title: EMS: Individual and Small Group Instruction for International Graduate   Students
LING 4.comments: Workload credit only. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LING 4.description: Designed for focused instruction in oral and written academic English.   Enrollment by instructor consent.  Preference given to students at   advanced proficiency levels.

LING 5.title: EMS: Intermediate Oral Academic English for International Graduate Students
LING 5.prereq_description: Graduate standing. Placement based on English Language Placement Examination
LING 5.comments: Workload credit only. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
LING 5.description: Focuses on listening comprehension and oral communication skills needed for effective participation in American university contexts, including small group discussions, one-  on-one interactions, and short oral presentations.

LING 6.title: EMS: Advanced Oral Academic English for International Graduate Students
LING 6.prereq_description: Graduate standing.  Placement based on English Language Placement Examination scores and TA English Language Evaluations.
LING 6.description: Intended to refine students' listening comprehension and oral communication skills in academic and professional settings, including graduate seminars, conferences and interviews.  Emphasis on formal presentations with peer and instructor feedback.

LING 7.title: EMS: Oral Communication for International Teaching Assistants
LING 7.prereq_description: Graduate standing.  Placement based on TA English Language evaluations.
LING 7.comments: Workload credit only. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
LING 7.description: Intercultural teacher-training course with an emphasis on pronunciation and the oral production skills necessary for successful communication in the American university classroom.

LING 8.title: Oral Communication for International Undergraduate Students
LING 8.description: Develops oral skills to help multilingual undergraduate students, especially international students, participate in classroom activities and engage in campus life. Activities include group discussions, group presentations, interviews, and language focus on vocabulary and pronunciation.

LING 9.title: EMS: English Pronunciation for International Graduate Students
LING 9.prereq_description: Graduate standing.  Placement based on English Language Placement
LING 9.comments: Workload credit only.  May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
LING 9.description: Intended to help students improve pronunciation of American English for  effective communication in academic and professional settings.     Instruction includes analysis and practice of vowels, consonants, stress and intonation patterns.

LING 10.title: Academic Reading Across the Curriculum
LING 10.description: Focuses on interrelations between reading and writing in academic content areas across the curriculum. Through engagement with readings in humanities, social sciences and sciences, the course provides essential reading strategies and skills for developing comprehension, genre awareness, and critical thinking.

LING 12.title: EMS:  Approaches to University Writing for Multilingual Students
LING 12.prereq_description: Open to students who have not satisfied the Entry Level Writing Requirement
LING 12.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
LING 12.description: Principles of critical reading, thinking and writing in the university. Students analyze academic discourse, develop rhetorical strategies for exposition and argument, practice examination writing, and write and revise papers. Completion of C or better meets Entry Level Writing Requirement.

LING W 12.title: EMS:  Approaches to University Writing for Multilingual Students
LING W 12.prereq_description: Open to students who have not satisfied the Entry Level Writing Requirement
LING W 12.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. LING W 12 is the online version of LING 12.
LING W 12.description: Principles of critical reading, thinking and writing in the university. Students analyze academic discourse, develop rhetorical strategies for exposition and argument, practice examination writing, and write and revise papers. Completion of C or better meets Entry Level Writing Requirement.

LING 14.title: Vocabulary and Grammar in Academic Writing for Multilingual Students
LING 14.description: Analysis and practice of English vocabulary and grammatical constructions for a variety of genres in academic writing. Focus on functional language use common across disciplines, such as expressing causation and change of state, creating cohesion, establishing focus and emphasis, qualifying ideas, and reporting research. Attention given to developing language resources and strategies for effective summarizing, paraphrasing and editing.

LING 15.title: Language in LIFE
LING 15.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
LING 15.description: Overview of language and its role in communities at home and around the  world. The diversity and history of languages; their norms, conventions, and written traditions; the role of language in culture and identity;  language rights and multilingualism, and the implications of technology  for language use.

LING 20.title: Language And Linguistics
LING 20.description: Introduction to the scientific study of language: The sounds of language;  word and sentence structure; semantics and pragmatics; discourse and   conversational speech; the social and cultural functions of language;  language change and the reconstruction of languages at earlier stages.

LING W 3C.title: EMS: Academic English
LING W 3C.prereq_description: Open to students who have a Ling 3C placement; or Linguistics 3B
LING W 3C.comments:
LING W 3C is the online version of LING 3C
Repeat Comments: LING W 3C can be taken as a legal repeat of LING 3C.
LING W 3C.description: Third level in a three-course series intended to develop proficiency in university-level reading and writing. Emphasizes applying critical approaches to reading, practicing writing in a variety of academic styles, and developing grammatical and lexical resources appropriate to a university setting.

LING 30.title: The Story Of English
LING 30.description: The evolution of English from its Germanic origins to its present status as a lingua franca among the world's cultures. Topics include influences from other languages, English-based creoles, the major contemporary  dialects, and the concept of Standard English.

LING 36.title: African-American English
LING 36.description: Examines the sociolinguistic aspects of English as spoken by African-Americans in the United States. Relationship of African-American English to linguistic theory, education policy, and U.S. culture. Emphasis on mitigating discrimination and improving the educational and social experiences of African-Americans at UCSB and beyond.

LING 50.title: Language and Power
LING 50.description: Examines how social identities and relations (nationality, class,    ethnicity, age, gender) are constructed, maintained, and challenged  via language practices, policies, and ideologies. Considers power  dynamics  in multiple domains including everyday interaction,  education, media  (advertising, news, film/tv, online), and political  discourse.

LING 60.title: Word Origins
LING 60.description: An introduction to the origin and evolution of words: language families, sound correspondences, and cognates; word-formation and loanwords;   changes in meaning and form; etymology; dialectal differences in lexicon;  vocabulary as historical and comparative evidence.

LING 70.title: Language In Society
LING 70.description: How language defines the relationship of the individual to society; the  role language plays in constituting power, hierarchy, ethnicity, gender, ideology, and other aspects of social identity; how speakers use   language to display identity and define social context. Emphasis on  sociolinguistic diversity in American society.

LING 80.title: Endangered Languages
LING 80.description: Examines language endangerment and its impact on the world's speech    communities. Topics include: language ecologies; reasons for language  shift; social, affective, and linguistic impacts of language     contraction; indigenous knowledge systems; biocultural diversity;    documentation, revitalization, and reclamation.

LING 101.title: Basic Elements Of Linguistic Analysis
LING 101.description: An introduction to the analytic methodology in the study of phonology,   morphology, syntax, and semantics. A typologically oriented course   designed to demonstrate how linguists analyze languages.

LING 102.title: Programming for Linguists
LING 102.description: Hands-on introduction to programming in Python, with emphasis on methods for retrieving, structuring, and interacting with textual data. Focus on developing practical programming skills and transferable methodology, such as debugging, task decomposition and abstraction, and best practices for documenting and structuring code. Targeted toward students with no programming background. May be taken for graduate credit using the LING 297 course code.

LING 104.title: Statistical Methods in Linguistics
LING 104.description: Fundamentals of scientific inquiry and methodology; basics of experimental design, statistical methods (descriptive, analytic, and exploratory) relevant to linguistics.

LING 105.title: Predictive Modeling in Linguistics
LING 105.description: Advanced methods in quantitative linguistics. Topics may include data exploration and visualization, classification trees, random forests, regression modeling, bootstrap methods, and Bayesian data analysis. Emphasis on building predictive models of linguistic data, with a focus on simulation, model comparison, and performance evaluation. Students complete statistical programming assignments and projects using real-world data.

LING 106.title: Introduction to Phonetics
LING 106.description: An introduction to the articulatory and acoustic properties of speech sounds. Survey of speech sounds found in the languages of the world. Emphasis on ear training and transcription using the International Phonetic Alphabet.

LING 107.title: Introduction to Phonology
LING 107.description: Introduction to the description and analysis of the sound patterns of  natural language. Focus is on developing analytical skills for     approaching data from a typologically diverse set of languages.

LING 108.title: Introduction To Morphology
LING 108.description: How meaning is encoded in words in the languages of the world.     Morphological and morphophonemic processes, lexical categories,    derivation and inflection, productivity, tense, aspect, mode, case,    concord, valence changes (passives, antipassives, benefactives,    causatives), morphological typologies.

LING 109.title: Introduction To Syntax
LING 109.description: Similarities and differences among languages in the grammatical devices  they use to signal relations between words in phrases and sentences.   Data from a range of languages presented and analyzed.

LING 110.title: Foundations of Computational Linguistics
LING 110.prereq_description: Linguistics 102 or Computer Science 8 or equivalent experience.
LING 110.description: An introduction to foundational ideas in computational linguistics, such as: n-gram language models; noisy channel models; supervised and unsupervised learning; and distributional semantics. Focus on developing an understanding of the intuitions behind the ideas, including relevant algorithms and math, and implementing this understanding in hands-on programming applications. May be taken for graduate credit using the LING 297 course code.

LING 111.title: Advanced Computational Linguistics: Text Processing
LING 111.prereq_description: Linguistics 110 or Computer Science 190I or equivalent background
LING 111.description: Advanced topics in the computational processing of language in text form, such as: neural network language models; parsing; topic modeling; and machine translation. Focus on developing a high-level understanding of modern approaches and how to use them. Discussion of applications to areas such as natural language processing, corpus linguistics, and computational psycholinguistics.

LING 112.title: Speech by Humans and Machines
LING 112.description: How humans speak and how machines simulate this process. Introduces speech technologies (speech synthesis and recognition) by highlighting the connection between developing such technologies and understanding the phonetic structure of speech. Considers applications of these technologies, such as human-machine interface and language learning.

LING 113.title: Introduction to Semantics
LING 113.description: Introduction to the study of meaning in language. Consideration of   semantic fields, semantic components, semantic relations, categories,  prototypes, frames, metaphor, pragmatics, indexicality, and speech acts.

LING 114.title: Advanced Phonology
LING 114.description: In-depth exploration of phonological systems and processes, survey of  contemporary phonological theories and critical assessment of their  effectiveness in accounting for established patterns       cross-linguistically.

LING 115.title: Introduction to Historical Comparative Linguistics
LING 115.description: An introduction to linguistic change, genetic classification of languages, and methods of reconstructing parent languages.

LING 116.title: The Structure of Language and Sports
LING 116.prereq_description: Upper division or consent of instructor.
LING 116.description: Examines the usage of language in organized sports, with analysis at   lexical, morphological, syntactic, discursive, and phonological levels.  Investigates how linguistic structure adapts to particular communicative contexts, such as media accounts and interactions among participants.

LING 117.title: Regional Dialects and Varieties of English Around the World
LING 117.description: Offers a comprehensive and in-depth survey of regional dialects of   English throughout America and around the world.  Examines dialect   variation through both descriptive analysis as well as socio-historic  accounts of the emergence of particular varieties.

LING 119.title: Advanced Computational Linguistics: Speech Processing
LING 119.prereq_description: Linguistics 110 or Computer Science 190I or equivalent background.
LING 119.description: Advanced topics in the computational processing of language in spoken form, such as: forced alignment; speech recognition; speaker recognition; and text-to-speech. Focus on developing a high-level understanding of modern approaches and how to use them. Discussion of applications to areas such as natural language processing, corpus linguistics, and computational psycholinguistics.

LING 120.title: Corpus Linguistics
LING 120.description: An introduction to computerized research methods which are applied to large databases of language used in natural communicative settings to supplement more traditional ways of  linguistic analysis in all linguistic subdisciplines.

LING 121.title: Field Methods
LING 121.comments: Letter grade required for majors. May be repeated for credit to a    maximum of 8 units.
LING 121.description: Workshop format with native speaker of a lesser-known language as    consultant. Students analyze the phonological, morphological, syntactic, and semantic structure of the language by eliciting data from the    consultant and applying the theoretical knowledge to the data.

LING 122.title: History of the English Language
LING 122.prereq_description: Linguistics 20; or consent of the instructor.
LING 122.description: Historical survey of English, from its Germanic origins to its     contemporary status as a global language. Topics include the phonology,  morphology, syntax and semantics of Old English, Middle English, etc., and the chief cultural influences at different stages of development.

LING 124.title: Discourse Analysis
LING 124.prereq_description: Linguistics 20 or 109, or consent of instructor.
LING 124.description: This course introduces students to the hands-on analysis of form and meaning in discourse, especially in naturally occurring conversation. Topics include referent accessibility, co-reference, and anaphora; resonance and coherence in dialogue; dialogue acts; constructions and information structure. Students learn to use basic computational tools for discourse analysis.

LING 127.title: Psychology of Language
LING 127.description: An examination of the psychological foundations of language structure  and use, including the cognitive processes involved in the     comprehension, production, and recall of words, sentences, and     discourse; first and second language acquisition; relationships among  language, brain, cognition, and culture.

LING 129.title: Sign Languages and Signing Communities
LING 129.description: An introduction to the linguistics of sign languages and signing communities, including early and current perceptions of deaf people and sign languages. Covers the emergence of sign languages and signing communities as well as the linguistic structures, sociolinguistic contexts, and acquisition of sign languages.

LING 130.title: Language as Culture
LING 130.description: Views language through the lens of culture, exploring language as a  sociocultural system that organizes meaning, memory, interpretation,   authority, action, practice. How practices of speaking shape culture;  intertextuality; linguistic and cultural relativity; relations between language, thought, and culture.

LING 131.title: Sociocultural Linguistics
LING 131.description: The study of language as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on language  use outside the U.S. context. Quantitative and qualitative approaches to regional and social dialects, register, linguistic power and solidarity, language contact and change, multilingualism, codeswitching, language  shift and loss.

LING 132.title: Language, Gender, and Sexuality
LING 132.description: The study of language as a resource for the production of gender and   sexuality across cultures. Topics include: gender differentiation in   language structure and use; intragender variation; language and    discrimination; linguistic ideologies; language and identity.

LING 134.title: North American Indigenous Languages
LING 134.description: Survey of the several hundred native languages of North America, including the history of research on these languages, their classification, special structures, and their oral traditions.

LING 135.title: Memes: Theory and Analysis of Cultural Evolution
LING 135.description: This course examines the meme as the minimum unit of cultural evolution. Equal time is given to the theory of cultural evolution and hands-on analysis of memes. Focus on internet and pre-internet memes, including image-macro memes, videos, humor, proverbs, songs, games, words, technology, and other units of cultural evolution.

LING 136.title: African-American Language and Culture
LING 136.description: The history, structure, and use of African-American English. Topics include: the sociocultural history of the variety's origin; language policy in schools and communities; representations of African-American English in popular culture; language and African-American culture; the use of African-American vernacular across the African Diaspora; and social issues.

LING 137.title: Introduction to First Language Acquisition
LING 137.description: An introduction to the interdisciplinary enterprise of understanding first language acquisition, overview of different theoretical and methodological approaches, and introduction to developmental processes in sub-areas such  as phonology, morphology, lexicon, syntax and semantics.

LING 138.title: Language Socialization
LING 138.description: What is the role of language in the process by which a child becomes a member of a particular culture? Topics include the acquisition of culture-specific ways of talking about emotions, enacting gender roles, having arguments and producing narratives.

LING 139.title: Introduction to Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
LING 139.description: Surveys theoretical and methodological issues related to teaching English  as a second or foreign language. Students examine current research and   pedagogy in TESOL and development in second language acquisition theory  and evaluate teaching materials and develop classroom lessons.

LING 140.title: English Grammar for Teachers
LING 140.description: Covers English grammatical structures commonly the focus of teaching   English as an additional language. Also considers key issues related to  grammar in language teaching, such as error correction and deductive   versus inductive methods of instruction.

LING 141.title: Second Language Acquisition
LING 141.description: An introduction to the theories and principles of how adults acquire a language other than their mother tongue, why it is more difficult than acquiring their first language, and what needs to be learned, from   linguistic, psychological and social perspectives.

LING 142.title: Phonological Typology
LING 142.description: An introduction to the diversity of sound systems found in languages of the world. Considers the cross-linguistic distribution of phonological patterns and their treatment in phonological history.

LING 144.title: Sociophonetics
LING 144.description: The study of phonetic variation as an aspect of sociocultural linguistic practice. Builds on knowledge of phonetics gained in LING 106. Focus on  exploring how to productively combine the theory and methods of phonetics  and sociocultural linguistics. Emphasis on the acquisition of analytical skills.

LING 145.title: Articulatory Phonetics
LING 145.description: An introduction to the speech production system, with special focus on the articulatory structure of speech and the relation of this    structure to the acoustic properties and perception of speech sounds.  Considers the speech of populations with speech communication disorders, and presents an array of experimental techniques used to investigate speech.

LING 146.title: Auditory Phonetics
LING 146.description: Introduction to the auditory processing of speech, including the physiology of hearing, neurological processing of speech, perception of pitch, loudness, and temporal properties, frequency resolution, models of speech perception, and hearing disorders.

LING 149.title: Intercultural Communication
LING 149.prereq_description: Any Linguistics or Communications course or consent of instructor.
LING 149.description: Explores communication (verbal, nonverbal, mediated) between people from different cultural backgrounds.  Topics include intersecting identities  (national/regional, race/ethnicity, linguistic, gender, sexual     orientation, etc.), intercultural relationships, cultural transitions, and intercultural conflict and dialogue.  Integrates insights from   social scientific, interpretive, and critical research.

LING 150.title: Language Documentation
LING 150.description: Issues in the creation of lasting multipurpose records of a language.  Documentation as collaborative, community-based initiative. Description  and documentation, archive creation, metadata, technologies,     materials, ethics, ethnography, orthography, and multimedia. Students  participate in a collaborative documentation project as primary    coursework.

LING 160.title: The Structure Of English
LING 160.description: Introduction to the phonological, morphological, syntactic and discourse features of contemporary English.

LING 170.title: Language in Social Interaction
LING 170.description: What role does language play in social interaction? How do individuals use language to shape relationships with others within or across social    groups? How do patterns of linguistic interaction constitute patterns of social organization? Emphasis on hands-on analysis of transcriptions and recordings of face-to-face interactions.

LING 175.title: Introduction to Romance Linguistics
LING 175.description: The course aims to illustrate principle of comparative-  historical    linguistic analysis by examining romance languages (French, Portuguese,  etc.) for similarities and differences, and tracing their evolution from vulgar Latin.

LING 180.title: Language, Race, and Ethnicity
LING 180.description: Linguistic practices of major ethnoracial groups in the United States, including African Americans, Asian Americans, European Americans, Latinxs, and Native Americans; examination of the linguistic effects of immigration and colonialism; bilingualism, translanguaging, language shift, and heritage language learning; linguistic interaction and contact between ethnoracial groups; language as a resource for ethnoracial identity; linguistic racism; linguistic activism.

LING 181.title: Languages of the World
LING 181.description: Introduction to the languages of the world: Geographical distribution; genetic (genealogical) classification, including comparison with genetics and archeology; structural properties and sociolinguistics of selected languages representing different parts of the world.

LING 185.title: Animal Communication
LING 185.description: The course will cover the basic terminology on animal communication  signals.  Special stress will be placed on the cost of signaling, and on the factors driving the biological evolution of communication.  Finally, animal communication will be contrasted with human language.

LING 187.title: Language, Power and Learning
LING 187.prereq_description: Departmental Approval Required to Finalize Registration.

LING 191.title: Internship in Linguistics
LING 191.description: Internship in a language-related work setting. Students apply concepts,  methods, and issues from linguistics to professional contexts in     education, business, government, nonprofit organizations and other   fields.

LING 192.title: Community Partnerships in Linguistics
LING 192.description: Service learning in a language-related volunteer setting. Apply concepts,  methods, and issues from linguistics to real-world problems in educational contexts, social service agencies, nonprofit organizations, and other  settings. Weekly report, and final paper required.

LING 193.title: Undergraduate Research Seminar
LING 193.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division course in
LING 193.comments: Misc: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters  and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all     193/199/199RA courses combined.
LING 193.description: Original individual or collaborative research in linguistics. Weekly   discussion of work in progress in a writing workshop setting.

LING 194.title: Group Studies In Linguistics
LING 194.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LING 194.description: Limited to small groups whose interest and needs determine the central focus.

LING 195A.title: Honors Thesis
LING 195A.comments: Students must have a 3.5 GPA in the major. A two-quarter in-sequence   course with final grade awarded upon completion of Linguistics 195B.
LING 195A.description: Guided research and writing of an original research paper to meet the  requirements of the honors program in Linguistics.

LING 195B.comments: Students must have a 3.5 GPA in the major. A two-quarter in-sequence   course with final grade awarded upon completion of Linguistics 195B.
LING 195B.description: Guided research and writing of an original research paper to meet the  requirements of the honors program in Linguistics.

LING 195C.title: Honors Thesis
LING 195C.comments: Students must have a 3.5 GPA in the major.
LING 195C.description: Guided research and writing of an original research paper to meet the  requirements of the honors program in Linguistics.

LING 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in
LING 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are  limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 193/199/199RA   courses combined. Admission by special arrangement.
LING 199.description: Intended for the study of special areas within Linguistics.

LING 200.title: Language and Linguistics for Non-linguists
LING 200.comments: Concurrently offered with Linguistics 20. Quarters usually offered:    Winter, Fall.
LING 200.description: Introduction to the scientific study of language:  The sounds of language; word and sentence structure; semantics and pragmatics; discourse and   conversational speech; the social and cultural functions of language;  language change and the reconstruction of languages at earlier stages.

LING 201.title: Research Methodology and Statistics in Linguistics
LING 201.description: Fundamentals of scientific inquiry and methodology; basics of    experimental design, statistical methods (descriptive and analytic)  relevant to linguistics such as chi-squared, testing of distributions  and means, simple correlation and regression.

LING 202.title: Advanced Research Methods and Statistics
LING 202.description: Multifactorial and multivariate statistical methods for analyzing    observational and experimental data in linguistics: basic linear and generalized linear modeling for numeric, categorical, count, and   proportion data; exploratory cluster analysis; graphical methods for data exploration.

LING 203.title: Phonetic Methodology
LING 203.description: Training in the use of quantitative phonetic techniques to perform linguistic analysis.

LING 204.title: Statistical Methodology
LING 204.description: More advanced aspects of (generalized) linear modeling (planned    contrasts, polynomials), robust statistics, mixed-  effects/multilevel   modeling; conditional inference trees; more advanced cluster-analytic  methods; bootstrapping.

LING 205.title: Programming for Linguists
LING 205.description: Hands-on introduction to programming in Python, with emphasis on methods for retrieving, structuring, and interacting with textual data. Focus on developing practical programming skills and transferable methodology, such as debugging, task decomposition and abstraction, and best practices for documenting and structuring code. Targeted toward students with no programming background.

LING 208.title: Foundations of Computational Linguistics
LING 208.prereq_description: Linguistics 102 or Linguistics 205 or Computer Science 8 or equivalent experience.
LING 208.description: An introduction to foundational ideas in computational linguistics, such as: n-gram language models; noisy channel models; supervised and unsupervised learning; and distributional semantics. Focus on developing an understanding of the intuitions behind the ideas, including relevant algorithms and math, and implementing this understanding in hands-on programming applications.

LING 209.title: Advanced Computational Linguistics: Speech Processing
LING 209.description: Advanced topics in the computational processing of language in spoken form, such as: forced alignment; speech recognition; speaker recognition; and text-to-speech. Focus on developing a high-level understanding of modern approaches and how to use them. Discussion of applications to areas such as natural language processing, corpus linguistics, and computational psycholinguistics.

LING 210.title: Advanced Computational Linguistics: Text Processing
LING 210.description: Advanced topics in the computational processing of language in text form, such as: neural network language models; parsing; topic modeling; and machine translation. Focus on developing a high-level understanding of modern approaches and how to use them. Discussion of applications to areas such as natural language processing, corpus linguistics, and computational psycholinguistics.

LING 211.title: Experimental Methods in Linguistics
LING 211.description: Provides hands-on experience in techniques required for the process of designing and analyzing psycholinguistic experiments.  This course   provides the opportunity to develop an experiment, from the formulation  of a research question to the interpretation of results.

LING 212.title: Discourse Transcription
LING 212.description: Methods for transcribing conversational discourse, with focus on discourse features relevant to linguistic and interactional research. Features include pause, laughter, intonation, voice, speaker overlap, turn-taking, participation, others. Recording natural conversation, computer-assisted transcription, transcription as theory, alternative transcription systems, transcription ethics/politics.

LING 213.title: Advanced Phonetics
LING 213.description: An experimental approach to the articulation, acoustics, and perception of speech. The relation of phonetics to phonological alternations and sound change. The use of phonetic data to resolve phonological questions. Interpretation and evaluation of experiments.

LING 214.title: Discourse
LING 214.description: Advanced research methods for analyzing discourse in light of grammar, and grammar in light of discourse. Hands-on analysis of naturally  occurring language use, especially conversational interaction. Topics  include referent tracking, topicality, information structure,    accessibility, constructions as functional units, functional niches,   preferred argument structure, dialogic syntax, resonance, narrative  structure. Theories of functional explanation for grammar; cognitive and interactional functions, competing motivations, grammaticization,    emergence of linguistic structure.

LING 216.title: Grammar Writing
LING 216.description: Training in writing a description of a language, including critical  review of selected existing grammars, discussion of contents, and    practice in writing.

LING 217.title: Discourse and Grammar
LING 217.description: Survey of recent approaches to discourse and grammar, including    referential pragmatics, dialogic syntax, construction grammar, preferred argument structure, and emergent grammar. Application of these approaches  to natural language data, including face-to-face conversation.

LING 218.title: Corpus Linguistics
LING 218.description: An introduction to computerized research methods, which are applied to large data bases of language used in natural communicative settings to supplement more traditional methods of linguistic analysis in all    linguistic subdisciplines.

LING 219.title: Corpus Construction
LING 219.description: Design and construction of electronic corpora to represent spoken or   written forms of language. Data collection from electronically available text/transcripts, linguistic fieldwork, archives. Issues of sampling,  balancedness, representativity, scale; formatting, markup, annotation,   coding, tools; archival preservation, orthography, politics, ethics.

LING 220.title: Prosody
LING 220.description: Perceptual and acoustic aspects of pitch, amplitude, and tempo and their interaction with discourse. Comparison of prosodic theories.

LING 221A.title: Field Methods
LING 221A.comments: A three-quarter in-progress sequence course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of Linguistics 221C.
LING 221A.description: Introduction to fieldwork and language documentation. Students work  with a speaker of a language unknown to the students for three     consecutive quarters. Techniques of data collection, elicitation,    management, and analysis. Emphases include collaborative research,   theoretical contextualization of field data, and descriptive and   theoretical writing.

LING 221B.title: Field Methods
LING 221B.comments: A three-quarter in-progress sequence course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of Linguistics 221C.
LING 221B.description: Introduction to fieldwork and language documentation. Students work  with a speaker of a language unknown to the students for three     consecutive quarters. Techniques of data collection, elicitation,    management, and analysis. Emphases include collaborative research,   theoretical contextualization of field data, and descriptive and   theoretical writing.

LING 221C.title: Field Methods
LING 221C.comments: A three-quarter in-progress sequence course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of Linguistics 221C.
LING 221C.description: Introduction to fieldwork and language documentation. Students work with a speaker of a language unknown to the students for three consecutive  quarters. Techniques of data collection, elicitation, management, and  analysis. Emphases include collaborative research, theoretical     contextualization of field data, and descriptive and theoretical writing.

LING 222.title: Typology and Universals
LING 222.description: Reading and discussion of major contributions to the literature in   typology and universals, focusing on such problems as lexical    categories, systems of case marking, voice, reflexives,      tense-aspect-mood, and relative clauses.

LING 223.title: Languages in Contact
LING 223.description: Types, causes, mechanisms, and consequences of contact induced     language change, including a consideration of pidgins and creoles.

LING 225.title: Semantics
LING 225.description: Introduction to the study of meaning. How meanings are integrated into linguistic sign systems, contexts of use. Pragmatic theories of    indexicality, deixis, implicature, presupposition, speech acts,    discourse comprehension. Semantic differences across languages.

LING 226.title: Cognitive Foundations of Language
LING 226.description: A psycholinguistic overview of the relationship between language and   cognition, including the nature of categories and the process of   categorization; processes involved in the production and comprehension of lexicon, syntax and discourse; priming; psycholinguistic models of  these processes and of first language acquisition; and the nature of mental representations.

LING 227.title: Language as Culture
LING 227.description: Examines language through the lens of culture, taking culture as the   pattern that gives meaning to social life.  Culture of linguistic    structure, practice, cognition.  Classic readings in linguistic    anthropology, sociocultural linguistics through current research linking language, thought, culture.

LING 228.title: Discourse Practice and Social Interaction
LING 228.description: This course explores language in action via the practices participants   enact in social interaction.  Focus on understanding linguistic action in  contexts of sequence, activity, stance, field, frame, intersubjectivity, dialogicality, voice, identity, participation, communities of practice.  Close analysis of recorded interaction.

LING 229.title: Linguistics of Sign Languages
LING 229.description: A comprehensive introduction to the linguistics of sign languages. Discussion of different theoretical and methodological approaches to investigating lexicons and grammars of sign languages, sociolinguistics of diverse signing communities, and practical, and ethical issues for conducting sign language research.

LING 230.title: Methods in Sociocultural Linguistics
LING 230.description: Field methodologies for research on language, culture, and society. Topics include ethics and politics of research, ethnographic methods,     interviewing, audio and video data collection, fieldnotes, relationship  between fieldwork and analysis. Students carry out original field research during the quarter.

LING 232.title: Foundations of Sociocultural Linguistics
LING 232.description: Investigates sociocultural theories of language as developed in    linguistics, anthropology, sociology, philosophy and other fields. A   comparative survey of the major theoretical issues in the field both   historically and in the present day, with an emphasis on the     relationship between theory and empirical analysis.

LING 233.title: Language, Gender, and Sexuality
LING 233.description: Advanced study of the linguistic dimensions of gender and sexuality.   Emphasis on the role of language in feminist theory and gender theory;   evaluation and application of research methods.

LING 234.title: Advanced Syntax
LING 234.description: Functional approaches to syntax. Methods of syntactic description and  explanation. Survey of clause-level syntactic structures in diverse  languages.

LING 235.title: Advanced Phonology
LING 235.description: Review of articulatory and acoustic phonetics and method of phonological description and analysis. Current issues in phonological theory. Survey  of phonological patterns and systems in diverse languages.

LING 236.title: African-American Language and Culture
LING 236.description: This advanced sociolinguistics course examines the linguistic, literary, cultural, and communicative aspects of African-American language across the African-American Diaspora. We blend diachronic and synchronic methodologies in order to create community-based participatory research approaches to the study of African-Americans and their language.

LING 237.title: Introduction to First Language Acquisition
LING 237.description: An introduction to the interdisciplinary enterprise of understanding first language acquisition, overview of different theoretical and methodological approaches, and introduction to developmental processes in sub-areas such as phonology, morphology, lexicon, syntax, and semantics.

LING 241.title: Topics in Phonetics and Phonology
LING 241.description: Specialized topics in phonetics and phonology.

LING 242.title: Advanced Phonological Typology
LING 242.description: Advanced study of the typology of sound systems found in languages of the world. Considers the areal and genetic distribution of phonological patterns and examines the treatment of these patterns in phonological history.

LING 244.title: Sociophonetics
LING 244.description: The study of phonetic variation as an aspect of sociocultural linguistic practice. Assumes familiarity with the fundamentals of phonetics. Focus  on exploring how to productively combine the theory and methods of   phonetics and sociocultural linguistics. Emphasis on the acquisition of  analytical skills.

LING 250.title: Language Documentation
LING 250.description: Issues in the creation of lasting multipurpose records of a language. Documentation as collaborative, community-based initiative. Description and documentation, archive creation, metadata, technologies, materials, ethics, ethnography, orthography, and multimedia. Students participate in a collaborative documentation project as primary coursework.

LING 251A.title: Seminar in Phonetics and Phonology
LING 251A.description: Specialized topics in phonetics and phonology.

LING 251B.title: Seminar in Phonetics and Phonology
LING 251B.description: Specialized topics in phonetics and phonology.

LING 252A.title: Seminar in Morphology and Syntax
LING 252A.description: Specialized topics in morphology and syntax.

LING 252B.title: Seminar in Morphology and Syntax
LING 252B.description: Specialized topics in morphology and syntax.

LING 253A.title: Seminar in Semantics and Pragmatics
LING 253A.description: Specialized topics in semantics and pragmatics.

LING 253B.title: Seminar in Semantics and Pragmatics
LING 253B.description: Specialized topics in semantics and pragmatics.

LING 256A.title: Seminar in Typology and Universals
LING 256A.description: Specialized topics in typology and universals.

LING 256B.title: Seminar in Typology and Universals
LING 256B.description: Specialized topics in typology and universals.

LING 258B.title: Seminar in Sociocultural Linguistics
LING 258B.prereq_description: Linguistics 227 or 228 or 230 or 232; and Linguistics 258A.
LING 258B.comments: May be repeated for credit. Must be taken for a letter grade.

LING 260.title: Advanced Language Change
LING 260.description: Types of theories of language change. Language families and subgroups. Internal and comparative reconstruction. The interpretation of     historical records. Dialectology; sociolinguistic factors in language  change and processes of grammaticization. Ramifications of observed  changes for synchronic theories of language structure.

LING 261.title: Syntax Beyond the Clause
LING 261.description: Functional approaches to the syntax of multi-clausal constructions,    including relative clause structures; complements; adverbial clauses;  clause chaining; and issues of clause-combining, co-ordination and   subordination.

LING 265.title: Acquisition of Grammar
LING 265.description: Theories, methods and cross-linguistic data in language acquisition;   focus on grammar. Evaluation of current theoretical controversies    concerning the mechanisms and bases--biological, cognitive, and social-- of language acquisition.

LING 271.title: Research Orientation
LING 271.comments: May not be applied toward the M.A. or Ph.D. degree requirements.
LING 271.description: Sequence of lectures by faculty of the Linguistics Department and closely  related departments, to acquaint new graduate students with current    faculty research, and with research directions and resources of the campus.

LING 272.title: Linguistics Colloquium
LING 272.comments: May be repeated for credit. May not be applied toward the M.A. or Ph.D.  degree requirements.
LING 272.description: Presentations on current topics in linguistics by visiting scholars,   faculty, and graduate students.

LING 273A.title: Language and the Body
LING 273A.description: Brings together the methods and findings of functional linguistics and   those of conversation analysis in a dialogue centering on the visible  behavior of the body in the organization of talk-in-interaction,     especially gesture, gaze, and body movement.

LING 273B.title: Language and the Body
LING 273B.description: Brings together the methods and findings of functional linguistics and those of conversation analysis in a dialogue centering on the visible  behavior of the body in the organization of talk-in-  interaction,   especially gesture, gaze, and body movement.

LING 274.title: Proseminar in Language, Interaction, and Social Organization
LING 274.comments: May be repeated for credit. Same course as Sociology 274 and Education 274.
LING 274.description: Discussion of current research, literature, and theoretical and    methodological issues in language and social interaction.

LING 281.title: Sociolinguistics
LING 281.description: Study of language as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on language use  outside the U.S. context. Quantitative and qualitative approaches to   regional and social dialects, register, linguistic power, and solidarity,  language contact and change, multilingualism, codeswitching, language  shift and loss.

LING 286.title: African American Language and Culture
LING 286.description: History, structure, and use of African American Vernacular English.    Topics include debates over the variety's origins; the politics of African American Vernacular English; representations of African American speech in popular culture; language and hip-hop culture; the use of African American Vernacular English by other ethnic groups; educational issues.

LING 288.title: Language Socialization
LING 288.description: What is the role of language in the process by which a child becomes a member of a particular culture? Topics include the acquisition of culture-specific ways of talking about emotions, enacting gender roles, having arguments and producing narratives.

LING 289A.title: Seminar in the Discipline of Linguistics
LING 289A.description: Specialized topics in the discipline of linguistics.

LING 289B.title: Seminar in the Discipline of Linguistics
LING 289B.description: Specialized topics in the discipline of linguistics.

LING 292.title: Linguistics in the Schools
LING 292.description: Pedagogical and sociocultural issues in teaching linguistics to K-12   students in formal and informal educational settings; designing    curricular materials based on research interests; participation in   collaborative hands-on teaching and mentoring.

LING 292A.title: Linguistics in the Schools
LING 292A.comments: Quarters usually offered: Fall. A three-quarter in-progress sequence   course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of Linguistics  292C.
LING 292A.description: Pedagogical and sociocultural issues in teaching linguistics to K-12   students in formal and informal educational settings; designing curricular materials based on research interests; participation in collaborative  hands-on teaching and mentoring.

LING 292B.title: Linguistics in the Schools
LING 292B.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter. A three-quarter in-progress sequence   course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of Linguistics  292C.
LING 292B.description: Pedagogical and sociocultural issues in teaching linguistics to K-12   students in formal and informal educational settings; designing curricular materials based on research interests; participation in collaborative  hands-on teaching and mentoring.

LING 292C.title: Linguistics in the Schools
LING 292C.comments: Quarters usually offered: Spring. A three-quarter in-progress sequence   course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of Linguistics  292C.
LING 292C.description: Pedagogical and sociocultural issues in teaching linguistics to K-12   students in formal and informal educational settings; designing curricular materials based on research interests; participation in collaborative  hands-on teaching and mentoring.

LING 297.title: Graduate Studies
LING 297.description: Graduate credit given for an upper-division course with additional work at the graduate level.

LING 299.title: Topics in Applied Linguistics
LING 299.comments: Same course as Education 299, French 299, German 299, and Spanish 299.
LING 299.description: Specialized topics in the study of applied linguistics.

LING 500.title: Teaching Assistant Practicum
LING 500.prereq_description: Appointment as teaching assistant and departmental approval.
LING 500.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
LING 500.description: Supervised teaching of undergraduate linguistics courses and instruction-related activities.

LING 505.title: Teaching Assistant Seminar
LING 505.comments: No credit allowed toward advanced degree.

LING 591.title: Research in Linguistics
LING 591.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree (prior course approval).
LING 591.description: Research under the direction of a faculty member(s).

LING 592.title: Writing in Linguistics
LING 592.description: Academic writing for publication in scholarly journals in linguistics.  Individualized meetings and/or small-group workshop format.

LING 593AAZZ.title: Seminar Paper
LING 593AAZZ.prereq_description: Completion of a Linguistics MA-level elective course.
LING 593AAZZ.description: The second quarter continuation of a MA-level elective course.  May be taken only once during a student's career to satisfy one of the Ph.D. level seminar requirements.  May not be taken as the continuation of an MA-level required course.

LING 594.title: Graduate Group Studies in Linguistics
LING 594.description: Limited to small groups whose interest and needs determine the central   focus.

LING 595.title: Lab in Linguistics
LING 595.description: Research and professional development activities in a collaborative lab setting.

LING 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
LING 596.description: Individual tutorial in any area of linguistics.

LING 597.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.
LING 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree.
LING 597.description: Instructor should be student's major professor or chair of the committee.

LING 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
LING 598.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.
LING 598.description: Instructor normally should be chair of the student's thesis committee. Only for research underlying the thesis, writing the thesis.

LING 599.title: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
LING 599.prereq_description: Instructor approval required prior to registration.
